questions.text: Lac operon transcription is induced by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lac operon's transcription is induced in the absence of glucose when an inducer, such as lactose, is present. This regulatory mechanism allows bacteria to preferentially use glucose when available and switch to lactose metabolism when glucose is depleted, optimizing energy production based on environmental conditions.
  • ➤ The lac operon's transcription is induced in the absence of glucose when an inducer, such as lactose, is present.
  • ➤ This regulatory mechanism allows bacteria to preferentially use glucose when available and switch to lactose metabolism when glucose is depleted, optimizing energy production based on environmental conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of recurrent headaches and pulsatile tinnitus in her left ear. She has also noticed a throbbing sensation in her neck, especially on the left side. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg in the right arm and 160/100 mmHg in the left arm. There is a prominent bruit heard on auscultation over the left carotid artery. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) should be considered in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, headaches, and a carotid bruit, especially with differential blood pressure readings between arms. It is a non-inflammatory vascular disease affecting medium and large arteries, leading to stenosis, aneurysms, or dissections.
  • ➤ Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) should be considered in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, headaches, and a carotid bruit, especially with differential blood pressure readings between arms.
  • ➤ It is a non-inflammatory vascular disease affecting medium and large arteries, leading to stenosis, aneurysms, or dissections.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with Familial Dilated Cardiomyopathy (FDC), genetic studies reveal mutations in genes encoding proteins crucial for maintaining cardiac adherens junctions. Which specific protein alteration is most likely to contribute to the pathogenesis of FDC?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of Familial Dilated Cardiomyopathy (FDC), mutations in genes encoding proteins that are part of the cardiac adherens junctions, such as β-catenin, can contribute to the pathogenesis of the disease by disrupting the structural integrity of the intercalated discs and myocardial architecture.
  • ➤ In the context of Familial Dilated Cardiomyopathy (FDC), mutations in genes encoding proteins that are part of the cardiac adherens junctions, such as β-catenin, can contribute to the pathogenesis of the disease by disrupting the structural integrity of the intercalated discs and myocardial architecture.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of left ear fullness and hearing loss. Examination reveals fluid behind the tympanic membrane, and impedance audiometry indicates a type B audiogram. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform myringotomy with grommet insertion to relieve middle ear pressure and facilitate drainage.

options.label: B
options.text: Conduct an endoscopic examination to rule out any underlying nasopharyngeal pathology, especially considering the unilateral presentation in an adult which may suggest a more serious etiology.

options.label: C
options.text: Instruct the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver, which can sometimes open the Eustachian tube to equalize middle ear pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe antihistaminics, assuming the effusion might be related to allergic etiologies.

questions.correct_answer: B. Conduct an endoscopic examination to rule out any underlying nasopharyngeal pathology, especially considering the unilateral presentation in an adult which may suggest a more serious etiology.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conduct an endoscopic examination to rule out any underlying nasopharyngeal pathology, especially considering the unilateral presentation in an adult which may suggest a more serious etiology.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal pathology can be diagnosed with endoscopic examination in an adult patient with unilateral serous otitis media, as it may be indicative of serious underlying conditions that could lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and middle ear effusion.
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal pathology can be diagnosed with endoscopic examination in an adult patient with unilateral serous otitis media, as it may be indicative of serious underlying conditions that could lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and middle ear effusion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman Yashi gives birth to her first child. She begins breast feeding the infant. She continues breast feeding for almost 6 months with no difficulties and no complications. Which of the following cellular processes that began in the breast during pregnancy allowed her to nurse the infant for this period of time?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Lobular hyperplasia

questions.text: What is the rationale behind xenobiotic metabolism by CYP enzymes?

options.label: D
options.text: Makes it suitable to evaporate through skin surface

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in water solubility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary rationale for the metabolism of xenobiotics, including drugs, by CYP enzymes is to increase their water solubility, facilitating their excretion from the body through urine or feces. This is a key concept in pharmacokinetics and is important for the safe and effective clearance of potentially harmful substances.
  • ➤ The primary rationale for the metabolism of xenobiotics, including drugs, by CYP enzymes is to increase their water solubility, facilitating their excretion from the body through urine or feces.
  • ➤ This is a key concept in pharmacokinetics and is important for the safe and effective clearance of potentially harmful substances.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to a rural clinic with a week-long history of fever, headache, and myalgia. He also reports noticing a black scab at the site of a recent insect bite. He works as a farmer and often walks through areas with heavy undergrowth. His vital signs are: temperature of 38.9°C, heart rate of 102 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg. A blood test reveals thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SCRUB TYPHUS
  • ➤ SCRUB TYPHUS
  • ➤ Most widespread Rickettsial Disease Causative agent : Rickettsia tsutsugamushi Vector : Trombiculid Mite (Leptotrombidium delinese and L. akamushi) IP : 10-12 days Typical clinical features : Eschar (punched out ulcer covered with a blackened scar, indicates location of mite bite) Weil Felix Reaction is strongly positive with Proteus strain OXK.
  • ➤ Most widespread Rickettsial Disease
  • ➤ Most widespread
  • ➤ Causative agent : Rickettsia tsutsugamushi
  • ➤ Causative agent
  • ➤ Vector : Trombiculid Mite (Leptotrombidium delinese and L. akamushi)
  • ➤ Vector
  • ➤ IP : 10-12 days
  • ➤ IP
  • ➤ Typical clinical features : Eschar (punched out ulcer covered with a blackened scar, indicates location of mite bite)
  • ➤ Typical clinical features
  • ➤ Weil Felix Reaction is strongly positive with Proteus strain OXK.

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertensive patient presents with fluctuating blood pressure readings, a double apical impulse, bilateral basal crepitations, and difficulty in ascertaining the heart rate due to an irregularly irregular rhythm. No murmurs were detected on auscultation. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of a hypertensive patient presenting with symptoms including an irregularly irregular rhythm and a double apical impulse, left ventricular hypertrophy is a possible underlying cause, especially considering the patient's hypertension. LVH can lead to changes in the heart's structure and function that may cause or be associated with arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation and complications such as heart failure, indicated by basal crepitations.
  • ➤ In the context of a hypertensive patient presenting with symptoms including an irregularly irregular rhythm and a double apical impulse, left ventricular hypertrophy is a possible underlying cause, especially considering the patient's hypertension.
  • ➤ LVH can lead to changes in the heart's structure and function that may cause or be associated with arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation and complications such as heart failure, indicated by basal crepitations.

questions.text: A young child presents with unusual hair texture, developmental delays, and a recent onset of convulsions. Given these clinical manifestations, which of the following conditions should be most strongly considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Menke’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menke's disease is characterized by kinky hair, intellectual disability, and seizures due to a genetic mutation affecting copper metabolism. This syndrome should be considered in children presenting with these specific symptoms, distinguishing it from other conditions with overlapping features such as intellectual disability.
  • ➤ Menke's disease is characterized by kinky hair, intellectual disability, and seizures due to a genetic mutation affecting copper metabolism.
  • ➤ This syndrome should be considered in children presenting with these specific symptoms, distinguishing it from other conditions with overlapping features such as intellectual disability.

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is commonly used as a source for external beam radiotherapy in the treatment of cancer patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cobalt-60 is the radioisotope commonly used in external beam radiotherapy for cancer treatment due to its emission of high-energy gamma rays.
  • ➤ Cobalt-60 is the radioisotope commonly used in external beam radiotherapy for cancer treatment due to its emission of high-energy gamma rays.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with progressive weakness, sensory disturbances, and difficulty with coordination. The patient is diagnosed with a demyelinating disorder, likely multiple sclerosis. Which one of the following statement is correct so as to consider it for managing the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Autoantibodies against MBP and MOG enhance myelin production, leading to neurological symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of autoantibodies indicates a protective immune response against demyelination.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoantibodies against MBP and MOG contribute to the demyelination.

options.label: D
options.text: Mutations in neuronal membrane proteins cause autoimmune reactions.

questions.correct_answer: C. Autoantibodies against MBP and MOG contribute to the demyelination.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In multiple sclerosis, autoantibodies targeting components of the myelin sheath such as MBP and MOG contribute to the demyelination process in the CNS, leading to the characteristic symptoms of the disease. The immune response in MS is pathogenic rather than protective.
  • ➤ In multiple sclerosis, autoantibodies targeting components of the myelin sheath such as MBP and MOG contribute to the demyelination process in the CNS, leading to the characteristic symptoms of the disease.
  • ➤ The immune response in MS is pathogenic rather than protective.

questions.text: When managing intractable epistaxis, which of the following vessels is not typically considered for ligation due to its importance in cerebral circulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Internal carotid artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While several arteries can be ligated to manage intractable epistaxis, the internal carotid artery should not be ligated due to the risk of cerebral ischemia.
  • ➤ While several arteries can be ligated to manage intractable epistaxis, the internal carotid artery should not be ligated due to the risk of cerebral ischemia.

questions.text: An adult old man gets burn injury to his hands. Over few weeks, the burned skin heals without the need for skin grafting. The most critical factor responsible for the rapid healing in this case is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Remnant skin appendages

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of partial-thickness burns, remnant skin appendages containing stem cells are the most critical factor for healing, as they provide the necessary cells for re-epithelialization and skin regeneration.
  • ➤ In the case of partial-thickness burns, remnant skin appendages containing stem cells are the most critical factor for healing, as they provide the necessary cells for re-epithelialization and skin regeneration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fixed dose combination of drugs is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Adverse effect of one drug may be neutralized by the other

options.label: B
options.text: In hepatic dysfunction, metabolism of both drugs is altered

options.label: C
options.text: Dose of one drug can be altered as per requirement

options.label: D
options.text: Adverse effect can be ascribed to a single drug

questions.correct_answer: A. Adverse effect of one drug may be neutralized by the other
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adverse effect of one drug may be neutralized by the other

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fixed dose combination (FDC) drugs can be formulated such that one drug's adverse effects are offset by the properties of another, improving therapeutic outcomes and reducing side effect profiles. It is a strategic approach in pharmacotherapy to enhance efficacy and minimize harm.
  • ➤ Fixed dose combination (FDC) drugs can be formulated such that one drug's adverse effects are offset by the properties of another, improving therapeutic outcomes and reducing side effect profiles.
  • ➤ It is a strategic approach in pharmacotherapy to enhance efficacy and minimize harm.

questions.text: A researcher is reviewing a study that analyzed the body temperature of different age groups. The study utilized a graphical representation to summarize the distribution of temperatures across various age decades. Refering to the graph provided, which type of statistical diagram is used to display the body temperature across age groups?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Line in Box : 2nd Quartile (Median) Whiskers end : Minimum & Maximum Values Edges of box : 1st and 3rd Quartile
  • ➤ Line in Box : 2nd Quartile (Median)
  • ➤ Line in Box
  • ➤ Whiskers end : Minimum & Maximum Values
  • ➤ Whiskers end
  • ➤ Edges of box : 1st and 3rd Quartile
  • ➤ Edges of box

questions.text: A male patient is brought to the ER after a car crash. He had dyspnea with chest pain and ecchymosis on the anterior chest wall. On examination, pulse rate is 120/min with BP 80/50 mm Hg, elevated JVP, and reduced breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Pelvis and extremities are normal. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the setting of trauma, the presence of dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, tachycardia, elevated JVP, and unilateral reduced breath sounds is highly suggestive of tension pneumothorax. This condition is a medical emergency and requires immediate intervention to release the trapped air from the pleural space and stabilize the patient.
  • ➤ In the setting of trauma, the presence of dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, tachycardia, elevated JVP, and unilateral reduced breath sounds is highly suggestive of tension pneumothorax.
  • ➤ This condition is a medical emergency and requires immediate intervention to release the trapped air from the pleural space and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: Given the importance of acetyl or acyl group transfers in various metabolic pathways, Identify a deficiency in which of the following nutrients would be most relevant to these transfer processes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pantothenic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pantothenic acid is essential for the formation of coenzyme A, which plays a vital role in biochemical pathways involving the transfer of acetyl and acyl groups, such as the citric acid cycle and fatty acid synthesis. Understanding the specific roles of different vitamins and cofactors in metabolism is crucial in biochemistry and nutrition.
  • ➤ Pantothenic acid is essential for the formation of coenzyme A, which plays a vital role in biochemical pathways involving the transfer of acetyl and acyl groups, such as the citric acid cycle and fatty acid synthesis.
  • ➤ Understanding the specific roles of different vitamins and cofactors in metabolism is crucial in biochemistry and nutrition.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the barium swallow shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Caustic Stricture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caustic stricture on a barium swallow as characterized by a narrowed esophageal segment with smooth, tapered margins.
  • ➤ Caustic stricture on a barium swallow as characterized by a narrowed esophageal segment with smooth, tapered margins.

questions.text: While analyzing the impact of acute blood loss on cardiac function by interpreting changes in the Frank-Starling curves, understanding how various clinical interventions or pathophysiological states affect stroke volume is vital. Given the patient's condition of mild hemorrhage and the associated compensatory mechanisms, to which point will the stroke volume shift from point X on the graph?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Point A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The compensatory physiological response to mild hemorrhage includes a reduction in preload and an increase in cardiac contractility due to sympathetic stimulation. On the Frank-Starling curve, this is represented by a shift of the operating point to a higher curve, indicating maintained or increased cardiac output despite decreased venous return.Top of Form
  • ➤ The compensatory physiological response to mild hemorrhage includes a reduction in preload and an increase in cardiac contractility due to sympathetic stimulation.
  • ➤ On the Frank-Starling curve, this is represented by a shift of the operating point to a higher curve, indicating maintained or increased cardiac output despite decreased venous return.Top of Form

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in breathing and a weak voice following a recent thyroidectomy. On examination, his vocal cords are visualized in a paramedian position. The patient's breathing difficulty is especially pronounced when lying down. The most likely cause of his condition has been identified, and a decision has been made to perform surgery to improve his airway without necessitating a permanent tracheostomy. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for this patient to widen the respiratory airway while preserving voice quality?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transverse cordotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) is the surgical procedure of choice to improve the airway in a patient with bilateral vocal cord palsy without compromising voice quality significantly.
  • ➤ Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) is the surgical procedure of choice to improve the airway in a patient with bilateral vocal cord palsy without compromising voice quality significantly.

questions.text: An infant present with mild anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly. A complete blood count with differential reveals spherocytosis; with elevated reticulocyte count. The parents state that several relatives have also suffered from a similar illness. The infant’s condition is most likely caused by defective:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ankyrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of hereditary spherocytosis is a defect in the red blood cell cytoskeleton, commonly involving the ankyrin or spectrin proteins. This leads to spherocytosis, characterized by hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly.
  • ➤ The most likely cause of hereditary spherocytosis is a defect in the red blood cell cytoskeleton, commonly involving the ankyrin or spectrin proteins.
  • ➤ This leads to spherocytosis, characterized by hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly.

questions.text: A child presented with history of ingestion of some unknown plant and developed mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, warm skin and delirium. Which of the following group of drugs is likely to be responsible for the symptoms of this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anticholinergic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The signs of anticholinergic poisoning, includes dilated pupils, rapid heart rate, dry mouth, warm and dry skin, and delirium. These symptoms are consistent with the blockade of acetylcholine receptors, which is characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity from certain plant ingestions.
  • ➤ The signs of anticholinergic poisoning, includes dilated pupils, rapid heart rate, dry mouth, warm and dry skin, and delirium.
  • ➤ These symptoms are consistent with the blockade of acetylcholine receptors, which is characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity from certain plant ingestions.

questions.text: A study conducted at a neonatal intensive care unit aimed to determine the influence of micropore tape on the accuracy of pulse oximeter readings. The researchers plotted the oximeter readings without micropore against those with micropore applied. Based on the scatter plot provided, what inference can be made about the relationship between pulse oximeter readings with and without micropore in neonates?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a positive correlation with a constant 3% increase in Y-axis value.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a constant negative correlation between two variables.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a constant positive correlation between two variables.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no correlation between the two variables.

questions.correct_answer: C. There is a constant positive correlation between two variables.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) There is a constant positive correlation between two variables.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PEARSON CORRELATION COEFFICIENT (r)
  • ➤ PEARSON CORRELATION COEFFICIENT (r)
  • ➤ A value of r = 0 indicates that there is no association between the two variables. A value 0 < r < +1 indicates a positive association; that is, as the value of one variable increases, so does the value of the other variable. A value – 1 < r < 0 indicates a negative association; that is, as the value of one variable increases, the value of the other variable decreases.
  • ➤ A value of r = 0 indicates that there is no association between the two variables.
  • ➤ A value 0 < r < +1 indicates a positive association; that is, as the value of one variable increases, so does the value of the other variable.
  • ➤ A value – 1 < r < 0 indicates a negative association; that is, as the value of one variable increases, the value of the other variable decreases.

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the data collected through the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project's P-FORM in a region known for its diverse ecology. The P-FORM is designed to report and monitor certain health events that have significant implications for public health. Which of the following health events is least likely to be under surveillance in this context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Snake bite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DISEASES COVERED UNDER IDSP (P-FORM)
  • ➤ DISEASES COVERED UNDER IDSP (P-FORM)

  • ➤ Acute Diarrhoea Disease (including acute gastroenteritis, Cholera)
  • ➤ Bacillary Dysentery
  • ➤ Viral Hepatitis
  • ➤ Enteric Fever
  • ➤ Malaria
  • ➤ Dengue/DHF/DSS
  • ➤ Chikungunya
  • ➤ Acute Encephalitis Syndrome
  • ➤ Meningitis
  • ➤ Measles
  • ➤ Diphtheria
  • ➤ Pertussis
  • ➤ Chicken Pox
  • ➤ Fever of Unknow Origin (PUO)
  • ➤ Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI) Influenza-Like illness(ILI)
  • ➤ Pneumonia
  • ➤ Leptospirosis
  • ➤ Acute Flaccid Paralysis < 15 year of Age
  • ➤ Anthrax
  • ➤ Plague
  • ➤ Any other State Specific Disease
  • ➤ Unusual Syndromes NOT Captured Above

questions.text: A patient is having ptosis and hypotropia. After administration of an intravenous drug to the patient, in 6 minutes his symptoms have resolved. The diagnosis of the patient is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Myasthenia gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rapid improvement of ptosis and hypotropia following intravenous drug administration in a patient suggests myasthenia gravis, which can be transiently treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, improving muscle strength and function by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • ➤ Rapid improvement of ptosis and hypotropia following intravenous drug administration in a patient suggests myasthenia gravis, which can be transiently treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, improving muscle strength and function by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Which of the following special amino acid is not formed by post-translational modification?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Selenocysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selenocysteine is unique among amino acids because it is incorporated into proteins during the translation process rather than being added through post-translational modifications.
  • ➤ Selenocysteine is unique among amino acids because it is incorporated into proteins during the translation process rather than being added through post-translational modifications.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with acute renal failure and anuria. The USG is normal. Which of the following investigations will give the best information regarding renal function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DTPA (Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetate) scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with acute renal failure and anuria, where the ultrasound is normal, a DTPA scan is the most appropriate investigation to assess renal function. It provides valuable information on renal perfusion and function, helping in the management and further diagnostic work-up of the patient's condition.
  • ➤ In patients with acute renal failure and anuria, where the ultrasound is normal, a DTPA scan is the most appropriate investigation to assess renal function.
  • ➤ It provides valuable information on renal perfusion and function, helping in the management and further diagnostic work-up of the patient's condition.

questions.text: Assertion : The intrapleural pressure will be negative or positive depending on the extent of respiration. Reason : The pressure in the space between the lungs and the chest wall will be sub atmospheric in nature. Which of the following is True?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the Assertion and the Reason statements are Correct, the Reason is the Correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the Assertion and the Reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: C. The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intrapleural pressure is consistently subatmospheric regardless of the phase of respiration.
  • ➤ Intrapleural pressure is consistently subatmospheric regardless of the phase of respiration.
  • ➤ Intrapleural pressure
  • ➤ subatmospheric regardless
  • ➤ phase
  • ➤ respiration.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent throat infections, missing several days of school over the past year due to sore throats and fevers. Examination reveals hypertrophic tonsils. The decision has been made to proceed with a tonsillectomy. Which of the following instruments is least commonly used during a tonsillectomy due to its risk of leaving behind residual tonsillar tissue?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microdebrider is least commonly used in tonsillectomy due to the potential risk of residual tonsillar tissue post-operation.
  • ➤ Microdebrider is least commonly used in tonsillectomy due to the potential risk of residual tonsillar tissue post-operation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient came for routine examination. On examination, a mid-systolic click was found. There is no history of rheumatic heart disease. The histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Myxomatous degeneration and prolapsed of the mitral valve

options.label: B
options.text: Fibrinous deposition on the tip of papillary muscle

options.label: D
options.text: Aschoff nodule on the mitral valve

questions.correct_answer: A. Myxomatous degeneration and prolapsed of the mitral valve
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myxomatous degeneration and prolapse of the mitral valve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical finding of a mid-systolic click on cardiac examination is highly suggestive of mitral valve prolapse, which is often due to myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve leaflets and associated structures.
  • ➤ The clinical finding of a mid-systolic click on cardiac examination is highly suggestive of mitral valve prolapse, which is often due to myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve leaflets and associated structures.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient has heart rate of 50 beats/min and taking tablet atenolol 200 mg/day in divided doses. After anesthesia, heart rate further fell down to 40 beats/min. What will be the appropriate treatment to improve heart rate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV atropine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For treating beta-blocker-induced bradycardia, especially in a perioperative setting, IV atropine is an effective and commonly used agent because it specifically counteracts the vagal-mediated reduction in heart rate without causing the extensive systemic effects associated with adrenergic agents like adrenaline and isoprenaline.
  • ➤ For treating beta-blocker-induced bradycardia, especially in a perioperative setting, IV atropine is an effective and commonly used agent because it specifically counteracts the vagal-mediated reduction in heart rate without causing the extensive systemic effects associated with adrenergic agents like adrenaline and isoprenaline.

questions.text: A patient presents with headache and Nuchal rigidity. Lumbar Puncture was performed and CSF shows normal protein and normal glucose with clear CSF. Microscopic examination of CSF showed 50 lymphocytes/cu.mm with lymphocytic pleocytosis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Viral meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of headache, nuchal rigidity, and CSF analysis showing clear fluid with lymphocytic pleocytosis and normal glucose and protein levels is most consistent with viral meningitis. This diagnosis can often be supported by the exclusion of bacterial, neoplastic, and fungal etiologies through CSF analysis.
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of headache, nuchal rigidity, and CSF analysis showing clear fluid with lymphocytic pleocytosis and normal glucose and protein levels is most consistent with viral meningitis.
  • ➤ This diagnosis can often be supported by the exclusion of bacterial, neoplastic, and fungal etiologies through CSF analysis.

questions.text: A child presented with hypotonia and seizures. It was a case of cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which is the accumulating substance in brain in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Long chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cerebro-hepato-renal (Zellweger) syndrome, the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids in the brain and other tissues is a hallmark feature due to the impaired function of peroxisomes, which are responsible for their breakdown.
  • ➤ In cerebro-hepato-renal (Zellweger) syndrome, the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids in the brain and other tissues is a hallmark feature due to the impaired function of peroxisomes, which are responsible for their breakdown.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old patient with a sudden-onset speech disorder, further investigations reveal a lesion in the left hemisphere involving the superior temporal gyrus and the posterior part of the left frontal lobe. The patient exhibits difficulty repeating spoken words without a corresponding impairment in language comprehension or production. Which intricate white matter tract is likely affected in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of sudden-onset speech disorders where the patient has difficulty with repetition but retains language comprehension and speech production, the arcuate fasciculus is the white matter tract likely to be affected. This tract's role in connecting Wernicke's and Broca's areas is central to the process of repeating spoken language.
  • ➤ In cases of sudden-onset speech disorders where the patient has difficulty with repetition but retains language comprehension and speech production, the arcuate fasciculus is the white matter tract likely to be affected.
  • ➤ This tract's role in connecting Wernicke's and Broca's areas is central to the process of repeating spoken language.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of atopy presents with several months of nasal congestion, stuffiness, nasal discharge, and a recent loss of smell. She reports a history of allergic rhinitis and has not responded to standard treatment for sinusitis. A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses reveals near-complete opacification with centrally hyperdense material and a peripheral rim of hypodense mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Allergic fungal sinusitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic fungal sinusitis on CT presents with sinus opacification with centrally dense material due to allergic mucin, which does not enhance with contrast.
  • ➤ Allergic fungal sinusitis on CT presents with sinus opacification with centrally dense material due to allergic mucin, which does not enhance with contrast.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male smoker Naresh presents with fever and cough productive of greenish-yellow sputum. The patient states that he has had morning cough with excessive mucus production for the past 5 years. Which of the following abnormalities would most likely be found in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Enlarged hilar lymph nodes on x-ray

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased Reid index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic bronchitis in smokers is characterized by increased mucus production and a corresponding increase in the Reid index due to hypertrophy of the mucous glands in the airways.
  • ➤ Chronic bronchitis in smokers is characterized by increased mucus production and a corresponding increase in the Reid index due to hypertrophy of the mucous glands in the airways.

questions.text: Development of hepatic central lobular necrosis secondary to acetaminophen overdose can be prevented effectively by which of the following if given within a few hours after ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prompt administration of N-acetylcysteine is critical in cases of acetaminophen overdose to prevent severe liver damage. NAC acts by increasing the levels of glutathione, a substance needed to detoxify the harmful metabolite NAPQI produced during acetaminophen metabolism.
  • ➤ The prompt administration of N-acetylcysteine is critical in cases of acetaminophen overdose to prevent severe liver damage.
  • ➤ NAC acts by increasing the levels of glutathione, a substance needed to detoxify the harmful metabolite NAPQI produced during acetaminophen metabolism.

questions.text: Public health data over recent decades reveal significant shifts in global health challenges. Initially, the primary health concerns were infectious diseases; however, modern statistics indicate a rise in chronic diseases due to factors such as urbanization, industrialization, and changes in lifestyle. This shift in health priorities is best described as:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epidemiological transition : A change in the pattern of disease in a country away from infectious diseases towards degenerative diseases.
  • ➤ Epidemiological transition : A change in the pattern of disease in a country away from infectious diseases towards degenerative diseases.
  • ➤ Epidemiological transition

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with mild haemoptysis. He also gave a history of hypertension and obesity. Lab data showed raised ACTH levels, which were not suppressed by high dose dexamethasone. The cause for the Cushing's syndrome in the patient is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ectopic ACTH secreting tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient presents with signs of Cushing's syndrome and tests show elevated ACTH levels that are not suppressed by high-dose dexamethasone, an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor should be highly suspected, especially in the context of a smoker with hemoptysis, where a paraneoplastic syndrome might be present.
  • ➤ When a patient presents with signs of Cushing's syndrome and tests show elevated ACTH levels that are not suppressed by high-dose dexamethasone, an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor should be highly suspected, especially in the context of a smoker with hemoptysis, where a paraneoplastic syndrome might be present.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child accidentally ingests a small portion of rat poison kept in the cupboard, while playing. The poison contains fluoroacetate, which combines with Oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate. Which pathway of the body is most likely to be inhibited by this poison?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoroacetate poisoning leads to the formation of fluorocitrate, which inhibits the TCA Cycle by targeting the enzyme aconitase. This inhibition disrupts cellular energy metabolism, highlighting the critical role of the TCA Cycle in energy production and the potential for targeted metabolic pathways to be disrupted by specific toxins.
  • ➤ Fluoroacetate poisoning leads to the formation of fluorocitrate, which inhibits the TCA Cycle by targeting the enzyme aconitase.
  • ➤ This inhibition disrupts cellular energy metabolism, highlighting the critical role of the TCA Cycle in energy production and the potential for targeted metabolic pathways to be disrupted by specific toxins.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms of kidney dysfunction, including fluid retention and elevated blood pressure. Further investigations reveal abnormalities in glomerular function. The healthcare provider suspects mesangial cell involvement. All of the following will cause mesangial contraction in the kidneys, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ cAMP typically causes relaxation of mesangial cells, thereby increasing glomerular filtration surface area.
  • ➤ cAMP typically causes relaxation of mesangial cells, thereby increasing glomerular filtration surface area.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with generalized edema. Urine examination revealed marked albuminuria. Serum biochemical examinations showed hypoalbuminemia with hyperlipidemia. Kidney biopsy was undertaken. On light microscopic examination, the kidney appeared normal. Electron microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:

options.label: A
options.text: Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells

options.label: C
options.text: Deposition of electron-dense material in the basement membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The typical electron microscopic finding in minimal change disease, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, is the effacement or fusion of the foot processes of the podocytes.
  • ➤ The typical electron microscopic finding in minimal change disease, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, is the effacement or fusion of the foot processes of the podocytes.

questions.text: Etanercept is a biological disease-modifying agent used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis. Its mechanism of action is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etanercept is a TNF-alpha inhibitor used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases. Its primary mechanism is to block the activity of TNF-alpha, reducing the inflammatory response that contributes to the symptoms and progression of these diseases.
  • ➤ Etanercept is a TNF-alpha inhibitor used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases.
  • ➤ Its primary mechanism is to block the activity of TNF-alpha, reducing the inflammatory response that contributes to the symptoms and progression of these diseases.

questions.text: A physician reviewing public health data notes an incremental rise in the incidence of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) such as diabetes and cardiovascular disorders over several years. This pattern is distinguished from seasonal or epidemic fluctuations in disease prevalence. What term best describes this long-term trend observed in the incidence of NCDs?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-term changes/sequelae of a disease are seen in Secular trend of disease.
  • ➤ Long-term changes/sequelae of a disease are seen in Secular trend of disease.

questions.text: A diabetic normotensive patient of Enterococcus faecalis sepsis, on IV Linezolid, developed high anion gap metabolic acidosis with increased serum lactate and negative ketone. The acid-base abnormality is most probably:

options.label: A
options.text: Type A lactic acidosis due to sepsis

options.label: D
options.text: Type B lactic acidosis due to Linezolid

questions.correct_answer: D. Type B lactic acidosis due to Linezolid
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type B lactic acidosis due to Linezolid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with high anion gap metabolic acidosis with elevated lactate levels and negative ketones, it's important to consider drug-induced lactic acidosis, particularly with medications such as Linezolid, known to cause this side effect. This is categorized as Type B lactic acidosis and is distinct from the hypoperfusion-induced Type A lactic acidosis commonly seen in septic patients.
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with high anion gap metabolic acidosis with elevated lactate levels and negative ketones, it's important to consider drug-induced lactic acidosis, particularly with medications such as Linezolid, known to cause this side effect.
  • ➤ This is categorized as Type B lactic acidosis and is distinct from the hypoperfusion-induced Type A lactic acidosis commonly seen in septic patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has had fever and dull pain in the left flank which radiates to left leg and an inability to pass urine for the past few days. She had a history of similar illness 6 months before. On examination, she has a tender abdomen and is anemic. Urinalysis shows presence of RBC, pus cells, WBC casts, characteristic hexagonal crystals, and amino acids. What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of characteristic hexagonal crystals in the urinalysis, along with the clinical presentation of flank pain, urinary obstruction symptoms, and aminoaciduria, strongly suggests cystinuria. This condition is marked by defective renal amino acid transport, leading to the formation of cystine stones in the urinary tract, which can cause recurrent episodes of pain and urinary tract infections.
  • ➤ The presence of characteristic hexagonal crystals in the urinalysis, along with the clinical presentation of flank pain, urinary obstruction symptoms, and aminoaciduria, strongly suggests cystinuria.
  • ➤ This condition is marked by defective renal amino acid transport, leading to the formation of cystine stones in the urinary tract, which can cause recurrent episodes of pain and urinary tract infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient is experiencing irregular menstrual cycles and seeking guidance from her healthcare provider. During the examination, the healthcare team explores factors influencing reproductive hormone regulation. Which of the following have a role in controlling the secretion of Prolactin?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of reproductive health issues, it is essential to consider the role of dopamine as the inhibitory regulator of prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary, as disruptions in this pathway can lead to clinical conditions such as hyperprolactinemia, impacting menstrual regularity and fertility.
  • ➤ In the management of reproductive health issues, it is essential to consider the role of dopamine as the inhibitory regulator of prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary, as disruptions in this pathway can lead to clinical conditions such as hyperprolactinemia, impacting menstrual regularity and fertility.

questions.text: Biopsy of a small, rounded rectal polyp demonstrates glands and sawtooth crypts composed of a proliferation of goblet and columnar epithelial cells as shown in the figure. No atypia is seen. This polyp is best classified as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyperplastic polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperplastic polyps are characterized by sawtooth crypts composed of a proliferation of goblet and columnar epithelial cells without atypia and are typically benign.
  • ➤ Hyperplastic polyps are characterized by sawtooth crypts composed of a proliferation of goblet and columnar epithelial cells without atypia and are typically benign.

questions.text: A patient of Prinzmetal’s angina is started on isosorbide mononitrate. What is the mechanism of action of nitrates in this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate alleviate angina primarily through endothelium-independent vasodilation of coronary arteries, which helps to relieve the coronary artery spasms characteristic of Prinzmetal’s angina. This effect is crucial for reducing chest pain and improving blood flow to the heart muscle during an angina episode.
  • ➤ Nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate alleviate angina primarily through endothelium-independent vasodilation of coronary arteries, which helps to relieve the coronary artery spasms characteristic of Prinzmetal’s angina.
  • ➤ This effect is crucial for reducing chest pain and improving blood flow to the heart muscle during an angina episode.

questions.text: A public health researcher is comparing the mortality rate from a specific cause in two different populations. To account for the differences in age distribution between the two populations, the researcher employs a method that adjusts the observed data to a standard population. Which of the following is an example of the indirect method of standardization the researcher is most likely using?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) : SMR = Observed deaths/Expected deaths × 100
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) : SMR = Observed deaths/Expected deaths × 100
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR)
